justification: The study introduces a novel 'change your mind' task where participants made two-alternative forced choices and had the opportunity to change their response after receiving spurious feedback. This task was designed to capture volitional cognitive flexibility in a context where rule learning or set-shifting was not required.
The paper explains that the WCST is used to measure the ability to transition between cognitive-attentional sets, highlighting its use in assessing cognitive flexibility.
The CANTAB test is stated to be employed for evaluating shifting and set-shifting tasks, contributing to assessing cognitive flexibility.
The DCCS is described as a task that measures the shifting abilities contributing to cognitive flexibility.

Task-switching tasks are mentioned as requiring participants to switch between two or more tasks based on pre-defined stimulus-response sets, illustrating their role in measuring cognitive flexibility.
